Author: luke#8628
Content: hello! someone mentioned a possible attack to me that would impact atomic swaps, and I was curious how barterDEX handles it. Let's say Alice wants to send BTC to Bob and receive ETH in return. My understanding is that Alice initiates the order, and a Bob accepts. Alice sends her deposit, which is 0.15% of the amount of BTC she plans to send. If Alice was malicious, after she sends her deposit, couldn't she sit around for 9 minutes until right before the next block is made on Bitcoin, to see if it is still favorable for her to make the trade (since the price of BTC may have changed by a lot more than 0.15% that she paid as deposit) and if she decides the trade is no longer beneficial to her, just not send her BTC effectively cancelling the trade? sure she would lose her deposit, but it would be a lot less than the amount she may lose on the trade. seems like attackers may try to take advantage of something like this. is this a known issue for atomic swaps? is it addressed by barterDEX?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The dex fee is less than that, and its not a deposit, its a fee, alice pays it and never gets it back.

Author: luke#8628
Content: ah, ok. I guess that would make this issue worse then right? because alice doesn't even need to consider getting her dex fee back. she is even more incentivized to cancel if not favoriable for her.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: She cant get it back

Author: luke#8628
Content: right, so she will be even more incentivized to not send her payment if the price of BTC changes in a direction that is unfavorable for her

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: until the trade is completed, it isnt completed and will be undone, other than the alicefee. for this fee, alice does get to play around with slippage, but realistically BTC wont usually be changing 5% in price during an atomic swap

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also a node that is bailing out half the time will soon get black listed and nobody would want to trade with your node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and making a new account would make you have to start building reputation from scratch

Author: luke#8628
Content: great, that makes sense. thanks @jl777c
